front.title: Proof of Process: Collaborative Authorship Extension

abstract.t: This document extends the Proof of Process architecture to support collaborative authorship scenarios where multiple authors contribute to a single creative work. It defines mechanisms for multi-author evidence chains, merge attestation when parallel branches are combined, and cross-author verification that preserves the provenance of each contributor's work. The extension enables Verifiers to determine exactly which portions of a finished work were authored by which individual.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Creative works are frequently produced by multiple authors working in collaboration. The base Proof of Process architecture captures evidence from a single Attester device, but real-world authorship often involves parallel editing sessions, shared documents, and merge operations that combine contributions from different authors.

This document defines the Collaborative Authorship Extension, which allows multiple Attesters to produce evidence chains that can be linked, merged, and independently verified. Each author maintains their own evidence chain signed with their own device key, and merge attestations record the points at which independently-authored content was combined.

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Multi-Author Evidence Chains
section.t: In a collaborative setting, each participating author operates an independent Attester that produces its own evidence chain. The evidence chains are linked by shared document identifiers and synchronized through merge points. Each chain MUST be signed using COSE_Sign1 () with the respective author's device key.

Authors are identified by their Attester public keys. When a new author joins a collaborative work, the existing authors MUST each produce a co-authorship invitation record that includes the new author's public key and a timestamp. This invitation record is included in every existing author's evidence chain to establish the point at which the collaboration began.

Each author's evidence chain operates independently and does not require real-time synchronization with other authors. The chains are linked only at merge points, allowing authors to work offline and reconcile their contributions later.

section.title: Merge Attestation
section.t: When contributions from multiple authors are combined into a unified document, the merging party produces a merge attestation record. This record contains the Merkle root of the combined document state, references to the head records of each contributing author's evidence chain, and a diff summary describing how the merge was performed.

The merge attestation MUST be encoded in CBOR () and signed by the author performing the merge. If automated tooling performs the merge, the attestation MUST still be signed by the device key of the author who initiated the merge operation. The merge record includes a transparency log entry () commitment to ensure the merge cannot be repudiated.

Verifiers validate a merge attestation by confirming that each referenced author chain is internally consistent, that the merged document state is a valid combination of the contributing chains, and that the merge signature is valid. Cross-author verification requires access to the public keys of all participating authors.

section.title: Cross-Author Verification
section.t: A Relying Party examining a collaboratively authored work may wish to determine the provenance of specific sections. The cross-author verification procedure traces content through merge attestations back to the originating author's evidence chain. This allows attribution at the paragraph or sentence level, depending on the granularity of the evidence records.

The verification algorithm walks the merge attestation graph in reverse chronological order, matching content hashes against individual author chains. For content that was modified during a merge, the algorithm attributes the modification to the merging author while preserving the original authorship record of the base content.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Collaborative evidence introduces the risk of collusion, where multiple authors coordinate to fabricate evidence chains that appear independent. The temporal binding provided by VDFs in the base specification mitigates this risk, as colluding authors would need to compute VDF chains in real time for each fabricated evidence record. Verifiers SHOULD examine the timing patterns of multi-author chains for anomalies.
